summary: glycyrrhizin (GL) is a triterpenoid saponin consisting of one glycyrrhetinic acid (GA) covalently linked with two glucuronic acids (GlcA) GL has also been used worldwide as a natural sweetener due to its sweet taste. conversion of GL into GAMG through chemical methods requires a boiling acidic solution and sophisticated instruments. biotransformation of GL into GAMG via -glucuronidases (GUSs) is an environmentally friendly approach due to the mild reaction conditions and the higher yield of GAMG. most GUSs have been classified as GH2 enzymes. a small number have been categorized as GH1, GH79, and GH30 enzymes. human endogenous GUSs and intestinal bacterial GUSs belong to GH2. many fungi, such as aspergillus terreus (33), A. niger, Penicillium frangnatum, and penicillium cyclopium (34) can convert GL to GAMG. but their low substrate specificities cause the further conversion of GAMG to GAMG. a fed-batch fermentation in a 150-liter fermentor was developed to transform GL into GAMG via T. pinophilus Li-93. all the GL was converted to GAMG after 42 h, while no GA was detected. the enzyme from strain Li-93 was induced by adding GL to the culture medium. GL catalyzed by culture supernatants of control strain P. pastoris GS115/pGAPZ and engineered strain P. pastoris GS115/pGAPZ-Tpgus79a respectively. Tyr276 was located parallel to the second glycan moiety of GL. the activity was tested by GL hydrolysis under standard conditions. glucuronidase from Aspergillus oryzae Li-3 in complex with GAMG was solved. a negative electrostatic potential was also observed in the active pocket of PGUS. this is the largest-scale preparation of GAMG through GL hydrolysis ever reported. a unique -glucuronidase (designated TpGUS79A) capable of selectively hydrolyzing GL into GAMG without the production of GA as a by-product was identified from the filamentous fungus T. pinophilus Li-93. TpGUS79A is in monomeric form in solution, with a molecular weight of 85 kDa. TpGUS79A is classified as a GH79 enzyme but shares very low sequence identity (less than 35%) with other GUSs from GH79. compared to other GUSs with low substrate specificity for GL (33, 40), TpGUS79A was more sensitive to heat and alkaline pH. most of the GUSs used for biotransformation of natural glucuronides showed much higher binding affinities and catalytic activities on artificial substrates. however, TpGUS79A showed the lowest binding affinity for pNP--GlcA (Km value of 25.56 mM) and the lowest activity on pNP--GlcA. TpGUS79A is a highly competitive biocatalyst ready to be applied in the production of GAMG through GL hydrolysis. it also displays activity on flavonoid glucuronides, such as quercetin 3-glucuronide and baicalin. but its activity on baicalin is much lower than those of the GUSs with high specificity for baicalin. the nucleophilic residues of GH79 GUSs from bacteria and fungi are located in the downstream conserved sequence (W/F)XXXGNE (45), which is quite different from those of plant GH79 GUSs and mammal heparanases (PGKKV-WLGE) and of GH2 GUSs. the gene for TpGUS79A was cloned and verified by heterologous expression in P. pastoris. a fed-batch fermentation in a 150-liter fermentor was established to prepare GAMG through GL hydrolysis by T. pinophilus Li-93. the vector PMD-19T and E. coli Top10 were used for gene expression. pNP-glucopyranosiduronic acid (pNP-GlcA), trypsin, bovine serum albumin, and glycyrrhizin (GL) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (San Diego, CA, USA) all other chemicals used in this study were of the highest analytical grade commercially available. the culture supernatant of T. pinophilus Li-93 was obtained by centrifugation (13,000 g for 10 min) the cell-free culture supernatant was mixed with ice-cold acetone at a 1:1 (vol/vol) ratio and centrifuged at 15,000 g for 15 min. the protein was eluted by using an increasing gradient of elution buffer (30 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.3, 500 mM NaCl) at concentrations ranging from 10 to 100% at a flow rate of 1 ml min1. the fractions with high specific activity were combined and used for further investigations. the scope of peptide mass fingerprinting (PMF) mass scanning was from 700 Da to 3,500 Da. the dominant peptides were selected for further analysis by secondary ion mass spectrometry.
